comments.body: Would it more sense to take a `Navigator` instead of a subset of `Navigator`'s attributes?

MaterialApp is supposed to be a one-stop shop for initializing the root of your app.  If we add a Navigator argument, we'll make every app more complicated.  I agree that it could be a problem if we spam too many properties onto this object...  I'm not sure what else to do besides taking one more step down this path.
The Navigator's properties aren't just passed through. For example, onGenerateRoute is hooked by MaterialApp, key is hooked by WidgetsApp.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +53,57 @@    this.home,
    this.routes: const <String, WidgetBuilder>{},
    this.initialRoute,
    this.onGenerateRoute,
    this.onLocaleChanged,

comments.body: Do you really want to describe this in Android-specific terms ("intent")?
It's just an example. Right now there's no automatic way to do this in iOS.

It really seems weird to me that our default localizations delegates don't actually create objects that are locale-specific. Maybe we should remove the "locale" field from these objects to make it more obvious that they are supposed to be constructed in a locale-specific way...

The MaterialLocalizations object is locale-specific, it's constructor only saves a reference to the resourceId=>value map for the specified locale. DefaultWidgetsLocalizations initializes its _textDirection field based on the locale.

I was just trying to make this foo-bar example as simple as possible; just to prove that you could get in the way of the default localizations.

I worry that people will think this is the way to localize your app, but yeah...

Maybe a better example would be to override something from en-US and have it say something different. Like, if you want to change your `timeOfDayFormat` to something else.
put a blank line after the first sentence. We use the first paragraph for short docs in various places.
never mind, just realised this is private
never mind, just realised this is private
never mind, just realised this is private
maybe mention the window manager in a second paragraph? or talk about specifics of where this is used on Android and iOS?
I didn't think "window manager" was a term that offered much to mobile devs, but explaining what exactly iOS and Android do with title would help.
